elements.content: The resolution of racemic 2-butanol through intercalation by a chiral metal−organic coordination polymer [Cu(PPh3)(N,N‘-(2-pyridyl-(4-pyridyl methyl)-amine))1.5]·ClO4 (1) constructed by an achiral building block provides new insight into the optical-resolution field. This provides encouragement for the role of crystal engineering in separating racemic mixtures and revives the historic practice of mechanically separating crystals of opposite chirality. Crystal data for 1:  C69H63Cl2Cu2N9O8P2, trigonal, R3, a = 13.7382(2), b = 13.7382(2), c = 32.72480(10) Å, α = β = 90°, γ = 120°, V = 5348.78(11) Å3, Z = 3, M = 1406.20, D c = 1.310 Mg m-3, R 1 = 0.0703, wR 2 = 0.1457, S = 0.928, T = 293 K, μ = 0.774 mm-1; crystal data for 1·1.5 (S)-2-butanol (2):  C75H78Cl2Cu2N9O9.5P2, trigonal, R3, a = 13.7282(4), b = 13.7282(4), c = 32.7155(12) Å, α = β = 90°, γ = 120°, V = 5339.6(11) Å3, Z = 3, M = 1517.36, D c = 1.416 Mg m-3, R 1 = 0.0454, wR 2 = 0.0605, S = 1.019, T = 293 K, μ = 0.783 mm-1.
elements.clean_text: The resolution of racemic 2-butanol through intercalation by a chiral metal-organic coordination polymer [Cu(PPh3)(N,N‘-(2-pyridyl-(4-pyridyl methyl)-amine))1.5]⋅ClO4 (1) constructed by an achiral building block provides new insight into the optical-resolution field. This provides encouragement for the role of crystal engineering in separating racemic mixtures and revives the historic practice of mechanically separating crystals of opposite chirality. Crystal data for 1: C69H63Cl2Cu2N9O8P2, trigonal, R3, a = 13.7382(2), b = 13.7382(2), c = 32.72480(10) Å, α = β = 90°, γ = 120°, V = 5348.78(11) Å3, Z = 3, M = 1406.20, D c = 1.310 Mg m-3, R 1 = 0.0703, wR 2 = 0.1457, S = 0.928, T = 293 K, μ = 0.774 mm-1; crystal data for 1⋅1.5 (S)-2-butanol (2): C75H78Cl2Cu2N9O9.5P2, trigonal, R3, a = 13.7282(4), b = 13.7282(4), c = 32.7155(12) Å, α = β = 90°, γ = 120°, V = 5339.6(11) Å3, Z = 3, M = 1517.36, D c = 1.416 Mg m-3, R 1 = 0.0454, wR 2 = 0.0605, S = 1.019, T = 293 K, μ = 0.783 mm-1.

elements.content: The resolution of racemic 2-butanol through intercalation by a chiral metal-organic coordination polymer [Cu(PPh3)(N,N‘-(2-pyridyl-(4-pyridyl methyl)-amine))1.5]·ClO4 (1) constructed by an achiral building block provides new insight into the optical-resolution field. This provides encouragement for the role of crystal engineering in separating racemic mixtures and revives the historic practice of mechanically separating crystals of opposite chirality.
elements.clean_text: The resolution of racemic 2-butanol through intercalation by a chiral metal-organic coordination polymer [Cu(PPh3)(N,N‘-(2-pyridyl-(4-pyridyl methyl)-amine))1.5]⋅ClO4 (1) constructed by an achiral building block provides new insight into the optical-resolution field. This provides encouragement for the role of crystal engineering in separating racemic mixtures and revives the historic practice of mechanically separating crystals of opposite chirality.

elements.content: Enantioseparation of racemic organic molecules by recyclable metal−organic coordination polymers or sieves through intercalation or inclusion has been a continuing challenge and ambitious goal for both inorganic and material chemists because enantiomerically pure compounds are of increasing importance to the fine chemical and pharmaceutical industries. In 1992, Mallouk and co-workers pioneered the optical resolution of organic molecules through intercalation by a layered phosphate with an optically active building block. Also, Kim and co-workers have recently employed the chiral building block (optical active or homochiral) to construct a chiral 2-D layered metal coordination polymer to resolve racemic [Ru(2,2‘-bpy)3]Cl3 (bipy = bipyridine) with a 66% enantiomeric excess (ee) in favor of the Δ form. More recently, we reported the first enantiopure 3D coordination polymer (a real zeotype analogue) used for the separation of racemic mixtures. This coordination polymer was constructed by joining Cd(II) centers with bridging chiral anions (quitenine, a modified quinine) to form a polymer that has the same connectivity as diamond. This enantiopure coordination polymer led to the successful separation of a racemic mixture of R- and S-2-butanol or R- and S-2-methyl-1-butanol with selective absorption of only one enantiomer into the homochiral diamond-type cavities with a 98% ee in favor of the S-configuration. Keeping this project going, our group more recently has used a chiral phase transfer catalyst as a building block to construct a novel 2D homochiral layered olefin-Cu(I) coordination polymer to resolve racemic 2-butanol with the R-enantiomer intercalated between layers. On the other hand, Rosseinsky et al. has employed chiral metal−organic coordination polymers constructed by achiral building blocks to resolve racemic molecules such as 1,2-propanediol with an ee value of approximately 26%. Shionoya et al. has also used a crystal engineering strategy to obtain a homochiral Zn-coordination polymer through spontaneous resolution. Aoyama et al. employed a crystal engineering strategy to construct chiral Cd-coordination polymers and measured their COD spectra. These successful examples are the extension of chirotechnology back to Louis Pasteur's historic discovery of spontaneous resolution in 1848 because a large number of chiral or helic metal−organic coordination polymers are self-assembled through asymmetric (or achiral) building blocks or crystal twist effects. Thus, successful access to the metal−organic coordination polymers constructed through achiral building blocks and capable of resolving racemic molecules seems to be very important not only for theory but also for practical economy and faces a great challenge now. At the same time, it is interesting to note that achiral molecules can also form an optically active crystal (a successful example is sodium chlorate crystallization). Our group has also successfully utilized this strategy to self-assemble some chiral 1-, 2-, or 3-D metal−organic coordination polymers through achiral building blocks. However, those chiral or helic coordination polymers still have not found a practical application for resolution yet. Furthermore, there is no clear solid-state structure report of chiral coordination polymers with a resolved guest especially for layered networks. With this in mind, as a continuation of our work, we have surprisingly found that the framework [Cu(PPh3)(N,N‘-(2-pyridyl-(4-pyridyl methyl)amine))1.5]·ClO4 (1) can crystallize in chiral space group and enantioselectively intercalate racemic 2-butanol. The solid-state structures of both framework 1 and the metal coordination polymer intercalated with one of the enantiomers have been determined. Herein we report the crystal structures of the framework 1 and its inclusion compound with a resolved 2-butanol molecule (Scheme ) in which 1 represents the first successful example of a chiral metal−organic coordination polymer constructed through an achiral ligand capable of resolving a racemic small molecular organic molecule.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Enantioseparation of racemic organic molecules by recyclable metal-organic coordination polymers or sieves through intercalation or inclusion has been a continuing challenge and ambitious goal for both inorganic and material chemists because enantiomerically pure compounds are of increasing importance to the fine chemical and pharmaceutical industries. In 1992, Mallouk and co-workers pioneered the optical resolution of organic molecules through intercalation by a layered phosphate with an optically active building block. Also, Kim and co-workers have recently employed the chiral building block (optical active or homochiral) to construct a chiral 2-D layered metal coordination polymer to resolve racemic [Ru(2,2‘-bpy)3]Cl3 (bipy = bipyridine) with a 66% enantiomeric excess (ee) in favor of the Δ form. More recently, we reported the first enantiopure 3D coordination polymer (a real zeotype analogue) used for the separation of racemic mixtures. This coordination polymer was constructed by joining Cd(II) centers with bridging chiral anions (quitenine, a modified quinine) to form a polymer that has the same connectivity as diamond. This enantiopure coordination polymer led to the successful separation of a racemic mixture of R- and S-2-butanol or R- and S-2-methyl-1-butanol with selective absorption of only one enantiomer into the homochiral diamond-type cavities with a 98% ee in favor of the S-configuration. Keeping this project going, our group more recently has used a chiral phase transfer catalyst as a building block to construct a novel 2D homochiral layered olefin-Cu(I) coordination polymer to resolve racemic 2-butanol with the R-enantiomer intercalated between layers. On the other hand, Rosseinsky et al. has employed chiral metal-organic coordination polymers constructed by achiral building blocks to resolve racemic molecules such as 1,2-propanediol with an ee value of approximately 26%. Shionoya et al. has also used a crystal engineering strategy to obtain a homochiral Zn-coordination polymer through spontaneous resolution. Aoyama et al. employed a crystal engineering strategy to construct chiral Cd-coordination polymers and measured their COD spectra. These successful examples are the extension of chirotechnology back to Louis Pasteur's historic discovery of spontaneous resolution in 1848 because a large number of chiral or helic metal-organic coordination polymers are self-assembled through asymmetric (or achiral) building blocks or crystal twist effects. Thus, successful access to the metal-organic coordination polymers constructed through achiral building blocks and capable of resolving racemic molecules seems to be very important not only for theory but also for practical economy and faces a great challenge now. At the same time, it is interesting to note that achiral molecules can also form an optically active crystal (a successful example is sodium chlorate crystallization). Our group has also successfully utilized this  strategy to self-assemble some chiral 1-, 2-, or 3-D metal-organic coordination polymers through achiral building blocks. However, those chiral or helic coordination polymers still have not found a practical application for resolution yet. Furthermore, there is no clear solid-state structure report of chiral coordination polymers with a resolved guest especially for layered networks. With this in mind, as a continuation of our work, we have surprisingly found that the framework [Cu(PPh3)(N,N‘-(2-pyridyl-(4-pyridyl methyl)amine))1.5]⋅ClO4 (1) can crystallize in chiral space group and enantioselectively intercalate racemic 2-butanol. The solid-state structures of both framework 1 and the metal coordination polymer intercalated with one of the enantiomers have been determined. Herein we report the crystal structures of the framework 1 and its inclusion compound with a resolved 2-butanol molecule (Scheme ) in which 1 represents the first successful example of a chiral metal-organic coordination polymer constructed through an achiral ligand capable of resolving a racemic small molecular organic molecule.

elements.content: The colorless prismatic crystals of framework 1 were harvested under solvothermal reaction conditions from [Cu(MeCN)2(PPh3)2] ClO4 and N,N‘-(2-pyridyl-(4-pyridyl methyl)-amine). In its IR spectrum, a strong peak at 1095 cm-1 clearly suggested the presence of a perchlorate anion in 1. The polymers (1·(S)-2-butanol or 1·(R)-2-butanol, perfect polyhedral and colorless crystals) with a small molecule alcohol were obtained by putting the sealed Pyrex tubes containing the mixture of 1 and racemic 2-butanol into an oven at 60 °C for 1 day.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The colorless prismatic crystals of framework 1 were harvested under solvothermal reaction conditions from [Cu(MeCN)2(PPh3)2] ClO4 and N,N‘-(2-pyridyl-(4-pyridyl methyl)-amine). In its IR spectrum, a strong peak at 1095 cm-1 clearly suggested the presence of a perchlorate anion in 1. The polymers (1⋅(S)-2-butanol or 1⋅(R)-2-butanol, perfect polyhedral and colorless crystals) with a small molecule alcohol were obtained by putting the sealed Pyrex tubes containing the mixture of 1 and racemic 2-butanol into an oven at 60 °C for 1 day.

elements.content: A simplified multilayer framework representation showing (S)-2-butanol is intercalated among layers.
elements.clean_text: 8  A simplified multilayer framework representation showing (S)-2-butanol is intercalated among layers.

elements.content: The solid-state CD spectrum in which the red spectrum is for framework (1) with (S)-2-butanol, while the dark spectrum represents framework (1) with (R)-2-butanol.
elements.clean_text: 9  The solid-state CD spectrum in which the red spectrum is for framework (1) with (S)-2-butanol, while the dark spectrum represents framework (1) with (R)-2-butanol.

elements.content: The 2-D polymeric structure of 1 (Figure ) was definitely confirmed by X-ray single-crystal diffraction investigations11a and is identical to the framework structures of [Cu(PPh3)(N,N‘-(2-pyridyl-(4-pyridyl methyl)-amine))1.5]·0.5CCl3·ClO4 7 and [Zn3(μ3-O)(C12H20N2O5)]·14H2O (C12H20N2O5 = tartaric pyridyl derivative)3 in which they all display a 2-D triangular cavity (red triangle) that is available for guest molecules intercalation as shown in Figure . In addition, the space-filling diagram of 1 (Figure ) clearly shows that a cavity is available for guest intercalation. Furthermore, there are two crystallographically independent Cu atoms in which their local coordination geometry can be best described as a slightly distorted tetrahedron defined by three N atoms and one P atom (Figure ), but three N atoms come from different pyridyl atoms. To investigate the position of anion perchlorate in 1, Figure shows that ClO4 - sits in the triangular center (green and red atoms represent Cl and O atom, respectively). It can be seen from Figure that adjacent two layers are in an ABAB packing mode.
elements.clean_text: The 2-D polymeric structure of 1 (Figure ) was definitely confirmed by X-ray single-crystal diffraction investigations11a and is identical to the framework structures of [Cu(PPh3)(N,N‘-(2-pyridyl-(4-pyridyl methyl)-amine))1.5]⋅0.5CCl3⋅ClO4 7 and [Zn3(μ3-O)(C12H20N2O5)]⋅14H2O (C12H20N2O5 = tartaric pyridyl derivative)3 in which they all display a 2-D triangular cavity (red triangle) that is available for guest molecules intercalation as shown in Figure . In addition, the space-filling diagram of 1 (Figure ) clearly shows that a cavity is available for guest intercalation. Furthermore, there are two crystallographically independent Cu atoms in which their local coordination geometry can be best described as a slightly distorted tetrahedron defined by three N atoms and one P atom (Figure ), but three N atoms come from different pyridyl atoms. To investigate the position of anion perchlorate in 1, Figure  shows that ClO4 - sits in the triangular center (green and red atoms represent Cl and O atom, respectively). It can be seen from Figure  that adjacent two layers are in an ABAB packing mode.

elements.content: To evaluate its enantio-separation for a small molecular alcohol such as racemic 2-butanol, we successfully determined the solid-state structure of inclusion compound 1·1.5[(S)-2-butanol] (2). Figure clearly shows that a molecule of 2-butanol exists in the asymmetric unit of 2. Because of the disorder of the 2-butanol molecule, it is hard to tell whether the (S)- or (R)-configuration is included in framework. This aspect can be solved by the known optical rotation value of (S)-2-butanol. Similarly, there are also two crystallographically independent Cu atoms with a slightly distorted tetrahedron. Furthermore, the space-filling diagram clearly shows that (S)-2-butanol molecules (balls highlighted in yellow) sit in a triangular center as shown in Figure . Each two 2-D layers intercalate (S)-2-butanol molecules, as shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text: To evaluate its enantio-separation for a small molecular alcohol such as racemic 2-butanol, we successfully determined the solid-state structure of inclusion compound 1⋅1.5[(S)-2-butanol] (2). Figure  clearly shows that a molecule of 2-butanol exists in the asymmetric unit of 2. Because of the disorder of the 2-butanol molecule, it is hard to tell whether the (S)- or (R)-configuration is included in framework. This aspect can be solved by the known optical rotation value of (S)-2-butanol. Similarly, there are also two crystallographically independent Cu atoms with a slightly distorted tetrahedron. Furthermore, the space-filling diagram clearly shows that (S)-2-butanol molecules (balls highlighted in yellow) sit in a triangular center as shown in Figure . Each two 2-D layers intercalate (S)-2-butanol molecules, as shown in Figure .

elements.content: (a) The solid-state fluorescent emission spectrum of framework (1); (b) the solid-state fluorescent emission spectrum of 1·(S)-2-butanol (2).
elements.clean_text: 10  (a) The solid-state fluorescent emission spectrum of framework (1); (b) the solid-state fluorescent emission spectrum of 1⋅(S)-2-butanol (2).

elements.content: Although it is possible to determine the absolute configuration of a single crystal of an enantiomer formed by means of crystal structure determination, quantitative determination of the ee of a bulk product by this method would be extremely time-consuming and exhausting, and, if the bulk product is microcrystalline, hardly feasible. Solid-state CD spectroscopy has been exploited to solve this problem and has proven to be a powerful tool for quantitative ee determination of bulk samples.
elements.clean_text: Although it is possible to determine the absolute configuration of a single crystal of an enantiomer formed by means of crystal structure determination, quantitative determination of the ee of a bulk product by this method would be extremely time-consuming and exhausting, and, if the bulk product is microcrystalline, hardly feasible. Solid-state CD spectroscopy has been exploited to solve this problem and has proven to be a powerful tool for quantitative ee determination of bulk samples.

elements.content: The spontaneous resolution achieved upon formation of a metal-coordination polymer prompted us to attempt separation of the homochiral crystals and furnish the included guest molecule 2-butanol in its enantiomerically pure form. Crystals of 1 were mechanically separated into groups according to each crystal identical CD spectra in solid state. The pellet KBr containing crystals of 1 are soluble in water, which permitted collection of solid samples 1 with identical CD spectra. The homochiral crystals of 1 are evacuated to collect homochiral 2-butanol below 100 °C.
elements.clean_text: The spontaneous resolution achieved upon formation of a metal-coordination polymer prompted us to attempt separation of the homochiral crystals and furnish the included guest molecule 2-butanol in its enantiomerically pure form. Crystals of 1 were mechanically separated into groups according to each crystal identical CD spectra in solid state. The pellet KBr containing crystals of 1 are soluble in water, which permitted collection of solid samples 1 with identical CD spectra. The homochiral crystals of 1 are evacuated to collect homochiral 2-butanol below 100 °C.

elements.content: To further confirm whether the intercalated 2-butanol is S- or R-conformation, the optical specific rotation of the 2-butanol obtained from evacuating homochiral 1·(S)-2-butanol in a vacuum was measured in which a minus Cotton effect begins in its CD spectrum (red line, Figure ). The result indicates that the optical specific rotation of the resolved 2-butanol has an identical value of the standard (S)-2-butanol. Thus, 1 represents the first example in chiral metal−organic coordination polymers with clear solid-state structures of both its framework and inclusion compound. On the other hand, the resolving capacity of 1 is also unprecedented in the chiral metal−organic coordination polymers constructed through an achiral building block and crystal twist effect. Finally, both framework (1) and included compound [1·1.5[(S)-2-butanol] (2)] at the solid state display strong blue-fluorescent emission at room temperature (Figure ). No difference between framework (1) and inclusion compound (2) is observed. Furthermore, we can tentatively assign the emission to ligand-to-ligand transition because a similar emission (λemax = 481 nm) is also observed for free ligand.
elements.clean_text: To further confirm whether the intercalated 2-butanol is S- or R-conformation, the optical specific rotation of the 2-butanol obtained from evacuating homochiral 1⋅(S)-2-butanol in a vacuum was measured in which a minus Cotton effect begins in its CD spectrum (red line, Figure ). The result indicates that the optical  specific rotation of the resolved 2-butanol has an identical value of the standard (S)-2-butanol. Thus, 1 represents the first example in chiral metal-organic coordination polymers with clear solid-state structures of both its framework and inclusion compound. On the other hand, the resolving capacity of 1 is also unprecedented in the chiral metal-organic coordination polymers constructed through an achiral building block and crystal twist effect. Finally, both framework (1) and included compound [1⋅1.5[(S)-2-butanol] (2)] at the solid state display strong blue-fluorescent emission at room temperature (Figure ). No difference between framework (1) and inclusion compound (2) is observed. Furthermore, we can tentatively assign the emission to ligand-to-ligand transition because a similar emission (λemax = 481 nm) is also observed for free ligand.

elements.content: In conclusion, 1, first demonstrating the resolution ability for a small molecule organic solvent, definitely provides new insight into an enantio-separation method by a chiral metal−organic coordination polymer self-assembled by achiral building blocks through crystal engineering.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, 1, first demonstrating the resolution ability for a small molecule organic solvent, definitely provides new insight into an enantio-separation method by a chiral metal-organic coordination polymer self-assembled by achiral building blocks through crystal engineering.

metadata.title:
Resolution of a Racemic Small Molecular Alcohol by a Chiral Metal−Organic
Coordination Polymer through Intercalation
